body:
> Would you accept enhancing the implementation of `EmptyArgumentsProvider` to also support the concrete types of the JDK?

The question is where to draw the line regarding which concrete types are supported.

As the Javadoc states:

> Subtypes of the supported types are not supported.

That was a conscious design decision to limit the maintenance scope of the feature.

In any case, the team will revisit this topic during an upcoming meeting.

My suggestion would be adding support for general purpose implementations only, i.e., the ones defined in the Collection Implementations section of the [Collections Framework Overview](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/collections/overview.html):


Interface | Hash Table | Resizable Array | Balanced Tree | Linked List | Hash Table + Linked List
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
Set | HashSet | Â  | TreeSet | Â  | LinkedHashSet
List | Â  | ArrayList | Â  | LinkedList | Â 
Map | HashMap | Â  | TreeMap | Â  | LinkedHashMap
Couldn't we check whether the type implements `Collection` and has a public no-arg constructor?
@marcphilipp your proposal looks good to me. Can I prepare a PR with this approach or rather wait for the official decision of the team?

Right after submitting my last comment, I realized that there are already collections having a public no-arg constructor that shouldn't be used in standard flows.

For example, from Hibernate:
* [`PersistentList`](https://github.com/hibernate/hibernate-orm/blob/0b2a357670ae41aac326f99d9c8b38f825f23989/hibernate-core/src/main/java/org/hibernate/collection/internal/PersistentList.java#L33-L37)
* [`PersistentSet`](https://github.com/hibernate/hibernate-orm/blob/0b2a357670ae41aac326f99d9c8b38f825f23989/hibernate-core/src/main/java/org/hibernate/collection/internal/PersistentSet.java#L36-L44)
* [`PersistentMap`](https://github.com/hibernate/hibernate-orm/blob/0b2a357670ae41aac326f99d9c8b38f825f23989/hibernate-core/src/main/java/org/hibernate/collection/internal/PersistentMap.java#L38-L46)

Not sure if this would be a point in favor of supporting only general purpose implementations of the JDK, where the behavior is well-known.

@scordio 
I would like to work on this issue, could you assign it to me?

@rgseyvie this is not really under my control and it's still in discussion with the team.

But I'd be happy to work on it by myself if it gets accepted ðŸ™‚
@marcphilipp I imagine this is still under team discussion and not something ready to be worked on, right?
**Team decision:** Add support for concrete types as proposed in https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2791#issuecomment-991193585.
